questions.text: Which of the following is NOT considered a secondary stabilizer of the knee?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL)

 

Explanation:

The PCL is a primary stabilizer of the knee, also known as a static stabilizer.


 

Static Stabilizers (Primary stabilizers)

Dynamic Stabilizers (Secondary stabilizers)
  • Fibrous capsule
  • Ligamentum patellae
  • Tibial collateral or medial ligament
  • Fibular collateral or lateral ligament
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Posterior cruciate ligament (Option D)
  • Arcuate popliteal ligament
  • Quadriceps femoris (Option B ruled out)
  • Popliteus (Option A ruled out)
  • Biceps femoris
  • Semitendinosus
  • Semimembranosus (Option C ruled out)
  • Plantaris
  • Gastrocnemius
  • Sartorius

questions.text: A 25-year-old football player presents with severe knee pain after sustaining a twisting injury during a game. On examination, there is swelling and instability. Lachman test is positive, and the valgus stress test at 30 degrees of knee flexion reveals significant instability. Which structure is NOT injured in a clinical setting of O'Donoghue's triad?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fibular collateral ligament (LCL)

 

Explanation: The fibular collateral ligament (LCL) is not involved in O'Donoghue’s triad, as it provides lateral support and resists varus forces.

 

Mechanism of Injury:

  • Twisting force on a semi-flexed knee- non-contact pivoting injury.
  • A direct hit to the lateral knee.

O'Donoghue triad: Injury to the medial collateral ligament, medial meniscus, and anterior cruciate ligament occurring together. It typically results from a lateral blow to the knee, leading to valgus stress and rotational forces.

Clinical features:

  • Deep knee pain.
  • Immediate swelling due to haemarthrosis.
  • Knee giving way feeling.
  • Difficulty ambulating.
  • Reduced range of movement in the knee.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male basketball player presents with knee instability following a non-contact pivoting injury. You perform the anterior drawer test with the patient’s knee flexed to 90° in the supine position, but there is minimal anterior translation of the tibia. However, the Lachman test shows increased anterior tibial translation with no firm endpoint. What is the reason behind the difference in the degree of tibial translational anteriorly between the two clinical tests?

choices.text: The anterior drawer test is more reliable for ACL injuries.
The Lachman test isolates the ACL better by minimizing hamstring influence
The anterior drawer test was performed incorrectly.
The patient likely has a partial PCL tear affecting the anterior drawer test.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The Lachman test isolates the ACL better by minimizing hamstring influence.

 

Explanation:

  • The Lachman test is more sensitive for ACL injuries because it is performed with the knee flexed at 30°, reducing the influence of the hamstrings.
  • The hamstrings may stabilize the tibia, limiting its forward movement during the anterior drawer test (performed with the knee flexed at 90°.

 

Anterior Drawer test:

  • The patient is in the supine position.
  • The knee is flexed to 90°. (Option C ruled out)
  • The examiner sits on the patient's feet to plant the foot.
  • The thumbs of both hands are on the tibial tuberosity and the examiner pulls it forward.
  • The test is positive if there is an excessive anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur.
  • It is less accurate than the Lachman Test. (Option A ruled out)

Lachman Test:

  • The patient is in the supine position.
  • Knee flexed to 30°.
  • The examiner stabilizes the distal femur with one hand and, with the other hand, pulls the tibia forward with the thumb on the tibial tuberosity.
  • The test is positive when there is increased anterior tibial translation relative to the femur.
  • Tibial translation of more than 5 mm indicated ACL rupture.
  • More reliable and more sensitive than the anterior drawer test because it is performed with the knee flexed at 30°, reducing the influence of the hamstrings, especially the biceps femoris.
  • Most sensitive for ACL injury assessment.

 

Pivot Shift Test:

  • Used to diagnose the rotatory instability related to injury of the anterior cruciate ligament ACL of the knee.
  • The test is performed by internally rotating the tibia while applying valgus stress on the knee and bringing the knee from extension to flexion.
  • In a torn anterior cruciate ligament, the valgus stress will cause the Tibia to subluxate anteriorly while the knee is still in extension.

The patient likely has a partial PCL tear affecting the anterior drawer test (Option D):

  • A PCL (Posterior cruciate ligament) tear typically results in posterior tibial translation, not a reduction in anterior translation.
  • Hence, this is an incorrect option

questions.text: A 28-year-old soccer player presents with a history of knee injury after feeling a 'pop' during a twisting motion on a slightly flexed knee while playing. He developed immediate swelling and pain in the knee. On examination, the Lachman test is positive. MRI confirms an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear. Which of the following is the gold standard imaging modality for diagnosing his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MRI

 

Explanation:

MRI is the gold standard for assessing ligament injuries, including ACL tears, with nearly 100% sensitivity and over 90% accuracy. It provides detailed images of soft tissues, such as ligaments and cartilage.

ACL Injuries: Investigation and Treatment

Investigation:

  • Mechanism of Injury: Typically occurs during axial-loading and twisting of a slightly flexed knee, common in pivoting sports.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Audible 'pop' at the time of injury.
    • Immediate knee swelling and pain.
    • Limited movement and difficulty with deep palpation.
    • Stability tests include:
      • Sag sign (posterior cruciate damage).
      • Anterior/posterior drawer test.
      • Lachman test (best for anteroposterior instability).
  • Imaging:
    • X-rays: Detect fractures (femoral condyles or tibial plateau).
    • MRI: Gold standard for ligament injuries (nearly 100% sensitivity).
    • CT: Identifies subtle fractures associated with ligament damage.

Treatment:

  • Non-Operative:
    • Quadriceps rehab and conscious knee control to minimize instability.
    • Modify activities to avoid risky movements (e.g., running, jumping, cutting).
  • Operative:
    • ACL Reconstruction: For symptomatic instability.
      • Goals: Stabilize joint, restore kinematics, prevent degenerative arthritis.
      • Common grafts: Autologous hamstring tendons or patella tendon.
      • Technique: Bony tunnels drilled in femur/tibia for graft fixation (e.g., screws, staples).
    • Rehabilitation: Focus on movement, strength, proprioception, and eccentric control.
    • Return to Sports: Not before 9-12 months post-surgery.
    • Prevention Programs: Programs like PEP reduce injury and re-injury risks.

Important Considerations:

  • ACL deficiency risks future instability even with rehab.
  • Many patients experience continued instability post-rehab.
  • Modern surgery aims to restore normal knee function with anatomical reconstruction.
  • Well-executed surgery can provide near-normal function at 18 months.

Imaging Comparison Table

Imaging Modality

Use

Sensitivity

X-ray (Option A ruled out)

Detect fractures (femur, tibia)

Moderate

MRI

Assess ligament injuries

~100%

CT (Option B ruled out)

Identify subtle fractures

High for fractures

 

Treatment Options Table

Treatment

Goal

Notes

Non-operative

Minimize instability via rehabilitation

Activity modification essential

ACL Reconstruction

Stabilize joint, restore kinematics

Grafts: Hamstring/patella tendon

Stepwise Rehabilitation

Improve range, strength, proprioception

Key for post-op recovery

Return to Sports

Gradual return after 9-12 months

Pivoting sports are the highest risk

Injury Prevention Programs

Reduce primary/re-injury risk (e.g., PEP program)

Proven effective in soccer players

 

Ultrasound (Option D) is not typically used for diagnosing ACL injuries as it lacks the detail needed to evaluate ligament damage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision where his knee struck the dashboard. He reports immediate pain and swelling in the knee. On examination, the posterior sag sign is positive. What is the most likely mechanism of his injury?

choices.text: Direct blow to the anterior tibia
Valgus stress applied to the knee

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Direct blow to the anterior tibia

 

Explanation:

PCL injuries commonly result from a direct anterior impact to the tibia, such as hitting the dashboard in a car accident, leading to posterior displacement of the tibia and PCL damage.

PCL Injuries: Mechanism, Clinical Features, and Tests

Mechanism of Injury:

  • Direct anterior impact to the tibia or rapid deceleration (e.g., knee hitting dashboard in car accidents). (Option B)

 

Clinical Features:

  • Initial symptoms resemble ACL injury.
  • Swelling: Acute hemarthrosis causes immediate swelling.
  • Pain: PCL injuries are painful.
  • Stability: Most patients regain function through quadriceps rehabilitation. Surgery is considered for persistent instability despite rehabilitation.

 

Tests:

Test

Method

Indication

Posterior Sag Sign

Observe from the side with knees at 90°, feet resting on the couch, for posterior sag of the tibia.

Reliable for PCL damage.

Drawer Test

Shift the leg forwards and backwards with the knee at 90° and the hamstrings relaxed.

Assesses anterior/posterior stability.

Lachman Test

Assess anteroposterior glide with knee flexed 15-20°.

More reliable for instability.

Quadriceps Active Test

Confirms posterior cruciate ligament insufficiency.

Confirms PCL insufficiency.


 

Hyperextension of the knee (Option A): This mechanism is more commonly associated with ACL injuries.

 

Twisting injury to the knee (Option C): Typically results in meniscus or ACL injuries.

 

Valgus stress applied to the knee (Option D): This stress is associated with medial collateral ligament (MCL) injuries, not PCL injuries.

questions.text: A 22-year-old athlete presents with a knee injury sustained during a basketball game. He reports immediate swelling and difficulty bearing weight on the affected leg. Physical examination shows a positive Lachman test, indicating increased posterior translation of the tibia. If imaging reveals a partial tear of the PCL, what is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate surgical reconstruction of the PCL
Application of a knee immobilizer and rest for 6 weeks
Open reduction and internal fixation of the ligament

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Non-operative management with physical therapy

 

Explanation:

Non-operative management with physical therapy is often appropriate for partial PCL tears, focusing on strengthening exercises and improving functional stability.

 

PCL Injuries: Investigation and Treatment

Imaging Techniques

Imaging Type

Findings

X-rays

May show avulsion fractures at PCL insertion on the posterior tibia; stress X-rays visualize posterior translation.

MRI

Gold standard for PCL diagnosis; provides detailed ligament images and detects partial tears.

 

Treatment Options

Treatment Type

Indications

Focus

Non-Operative (Option A)

Isolated PCL injuries, especially in low-demand patients.

Quadriceps strengthening, regain range of motion.

Operative (Option B ruled out)

Patients with persistent instability, functional limitations, or significant bony avulsions.

PCL reconstruction or open reduction and fixation for avulsions.

Bony PCL Avulsions

  • Mechanism: Commonly traction injuries, particularly in adolescents.
  • Management:
    • Undisplaced: Non-operative, using a brace or cast.
    • Displaced: Operative reduction and fixation.

Application of a knee immobilizer and rest for 6 weeks (Option C): While a knee immobilizer can provide temporary relief and stability, it is generally not the preferred long-term management for a partial PCL tear. Immobilization for an extended period can lead to muscle atrophy and joint stiffness, which can hinder recovery.

 

Open reduction and internal fixation of the ligament (Option D): This is not applicable for a PCL injury; reconstruction is the typical approach if surgery is needed.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with knee pain and reports that he feels a "catching" sensation during movement after a recent sports injury. On examination, there is localized tenderness along the joint line, and he experiences difficulty fully extending the knee. Which of the following clinical features is most characteristic of a meniscal tear?

choices.text: Pain on passive extension of the knee
Locking of the knee during movement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Locking of the knee during movement

 

Explanation:

  • The most characteristic clinical feature of a meniscal tear is locking of the knee during movement.
  • This symptom, along with the “catching” sensation and joint line tenderness, strongly suggests a meniscal injury

 

Meniscal Injuries:

Anatomy of the Menisci

  • Location: Fibrocartilaginous structures between femur and tibia in the knee joint.
  • Types:
    • Medial Meniscus: Inner side of the knee; less mobile and more prone to injury due to capsule attachments.
    • Lateral Meniscus: Outer side of the knee; more mobile than the medial meniscus.
  • Structure: Composed of circumferential collagen fibers with radial strands; prone to longitudinal tears.
  • Functions:
    • Aids proprioception through mechanoreceptors that detect joint motion and position.
    • Enhance joint stability and congruency.
    • Facilitate smooth knee motion.
    • Distribute load during weight-bearing (50% in extension; up to 90% in flexion).

Mechanism of Meniscal Tears

  • Common Causes:
    • Rotational and Shearing Forces: Twisting a flexed knee under weight (common in sports).
    • Age-Related Degeneration: Reduced mobility in older adults leads to tears with minimal force.
  • Tear Mechanism by Age:
    • Younger Individuals: Traumatic tears from specific sports incidents.
    • Older Individuals: Tears may occur with less force due to degenerative changes, often without a distinct injury.


 

Clinical Features of Meniscal Tears

Symptom/ Feature

Description

Pain

Localized to the joint line, particularly medial; worsens with activities stressing the meniscus.

Swelling

Delayed onset, usually hours after injury; presents as effusion. (Option A ruled out)

Mechanical Symptoms
  • Locking: Difficulty fully extending the knee; suggests "bucket-handle" tear. (Option C)
  • Catching: Sensation of knee getting stuck, indicating loose fragment.
  • Giving Way: Knee buckling during twisting movements, suggesting instability.

Examination Findings
  • Tenderness: Localized along the joint line, typically medial.
  • Limited Extension: Difficulty achieving full knee extension.
  • Quadriceps Wasting: Possible in chronic cases.
  • Special Tests: Clinical tests (McMurray's, Apley's, Thessaly) assist diagnosis; MRI is the gold standard.

 

Pain on passive extension (Option B) is more indicative of ligamentous injuries rather than meniscal tears.

 

Dislocation of the knee (Option D) joint is not a feature of meniscal tears; it suggests a more severe injury or instability.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with knee pain following a twisting injury while playing football. On examination, the patient exhibits localized tenderness along the medial joint line, and the examiner suspects a meniscal tear. Which of the following clinical tests would provide the highest diagnostic accuracy for detecting a meniscal tear in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thessaly Test

 

Explanation:

Thessaly Test has demonstrated high diagnostic accuracy (95%) for detecting meniscal tears, making it the most reliable choice.

Clinical Tests for Meniscal Injuries

Tests

Clinical tests aim to diagnose meniscal injuries by eliciting pain or reproducing symptoms through specific stresses.

Test Name

Procedure Description

Positive Sign

Reliability

McMurray's Test

Knee is flexed; examiner stabilizes while rotating the leg. Knee is slowly extended with maintained rotation.

Palpable or audible click during extension.

Not highly reliable; low sensitivity and specificity. (Option A ruled out)

Thessaly Test

Patient stands on the affected leg with the knee flexed at 20 degrees; twists the body while maintaining knee flexion.

Medial or lateral joint line pain or locking sensation.

High diagnostic accuracy (95%); low false-positive/negative rates. (Option C)

Apley's Test

Patient lies prone with knee flexed at 90 degrees; the examiner applies compression (Apley's Grinding Test) or distraction (Apley's Distraction Test) during tibia rotation.


 

Pain with compression suggests meniscal tear; pain with distraction suggests ligament damage.

Not specified; results depend on specific findings. (Options B & D ruled out)

Additional Clinical Findings

Important considerations alongside specific tests include:

  • Mechanism of Injury: Twisting injury to a flexed knee suggests a meniscal tear.
  • Localized Tenderness: Tenderness along the joint line, especially medially, indicates potential meniscal tears.
  • Joint Effusion: Swelling often occurs several hours post-injury.
  • Limited Range of Motion: Difficulty achieving full knee extension.
  • Quadriceps Wasting: May indicate chronic cases.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with knee pain following a twisting injury while playing football. On examination, he exhibits joint line tenderness, effusion, and a limited range of motion. An MRI confirms a meniscal tear. Which of the following statements regarding the management of his condition is most accurate?

choices.text: Total meniscectomy is preferred to prevent future complications.
Conservative treatment includes immobilization and complete rest.
Meniscal repair is a suitable option for tears in the vascularized peripheral zone.
X-rays are definitive for diagnosing meniscal injuries.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Meniscal repair is a suitable option for tears in the vascularized peripheral zone.

 

Explanation:

Meniscal repair is appropriate for tears in the vascularized peripheral zone, especially in younger patients.

Meniscal Injury: Investigation and Treatment

Investigation

  • Physical Examination:
    • Essential for diagnosing meniscal injuries.
    • Signs of meniscal tears:
      • Joint line tenderness
      • Effusion
      • Limited range of motion
      • History of twisting injury to a flexed knee
  • Imaging Techniques:
    • X-rays:
      • Not used to visualize meniscal tears directly.
      • Useful for ruling out fractures and identifying degenerative changes.
    • MRI:
      • Gold standard for diagnosing meniscal injuries. (Option D ruled out)
      • Provides detailed images for identifying tear type, location, and size.


 

Treatment

Treatment Type

Indications

Management

Conservative Treatment

First-line for non-locked joints; small tears in vascular zone

RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation), NSAIDs, physical therapy focused on range of motion and strengthening (Option B ruled out)

Operative Treatment

Considered when:

The knee is locked due to a displaced meniscal tear.

Conservative treatment has failed, and mechanical symptoms (like locking or catching) continue.

Surgical options include:

Meniscal Repair: Suture torn edges in vascular zone; promotes healing. (Option C)

Partial Meniscectomy: Remove torn portion in avascular zone; preserve healthy tissue.

Total Meniscectomy: Generally avoided due to increased risk of joint instability and osteoarthritis. (Option A ruled out)

Postoperative Care and Rehabilitation

  • Early Range of Motion: Initiate gentle exercises to prevent stiffness.
  • Progressive Strengthening: Gradually introduce quadriceps and hamstring exercises for stability.
  • Functional Exercises: Incorporate activities mimicking daily tasks for a safe return to activities.

questions.text: A 27-year-old basketball player presents with lateral knee pain after a twisting injury during a game. Physical examination reveals a positive varus stress test. Imaging shows an isolated lateral collateral ligament (LCL) tear with a small bony avulsion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Surgical repair

 

Explanation:

Bony avulsions associated with LCL injuries often require surgical intervention to reattach the ligament and restore knee stability.

MCL and LCL Injuries

  • Common knee injuries, especially in athletes, often caused by impact or twisting forces.
  • MCL injuries: Result from a valgus (inward) force on the knee.
  • LCL injuries: Caused by a varus (outward) force on the knee.
  • Injury severity ranges from sprains to complete tears.
  • Imaging: X-rays, MRI

Corticosteroid injection (Option B): Not indicated for acute ligament injuries or bony avulsions.

 

Total knee arthroplasty (Option D): Not appropriate in a young athlete with an acute ligament injury.

Learning objective:

Injury Type

Common Cause

Severity

Treatment

Surgical Need

MCL

Valgus force (inward)

Sprains to complete tears

Partial tear/ Low grade full-thickness tears: Conservative (bracing) for partial/low-grade tears

Yes, for complete tears or chronic instability.

LCL

Varus force (outward)

Often combined with PLC injuries

Isolates LCL Injury: Conservative (bracing) (Option A ruled out)

Yes, for bony avulsions or PLC injuries. (Option C)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male football player presents to the emergency department after sustaining a lateral blow to his knee during a game. He complains of immediate swelling, pain, and instability in the knee. On physical examination, there is tenderness along the medial aspect of the knee and a positive anterior drawer test. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this type of injury?

choices.text: Lateral collateral ligament, anterior cruciate ligament, and lateral meniscus
Medial collateral ligament, anterior cruciate ligament, and medial meniscus
Posterior cruciate ligament, medial collateral ligament, and lateral meniscus
Medial collateral ligament, posterior cruciate ligament, and medial meniscus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Medial collateral ligament, anterior cruciate ligament, and medial meniscus

 

Explanation:

The "unhappy triad" involves injury to the medial collateral ligament (MCL), anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), and medial meniscus, typically due to a lateral blow with the foot planted, leading to valgus force and rotational instability.

Unhappy Triad

The unhappy triad (or terrible triad) refers to a common knee injury caused by a lateral blow to the knee with the foot planted.

  • Components Involved:
    • Medial collateral ligament (MCL)
    • Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)
    • Medial meniscus

Mechanism of Injury

  • Lateral blow: Causes inward bending of the knee (valgus force).
  • MCL tear: Due to stretching from valgus force.
  • ACL tear: Result of twisting motion, affecting rotational stability.
  • Medial meniscus tear: More prone to injury than the lateral meniscus due to limited mobility.

Key Characteristics of Injury

  • Symptoms:
    • Pain and immediate swelling (due to hemarthrosis)
    • Knee instability
  • Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination
    • Stress X-rays
    • MRI imaging

Treatment

  • Surgical intervention: Typically required to repair or reconstruct damaged ligaments and meniscus for knee stability and function.

Lateral collateral ligament, anterior cruciate ligament, and lateral meniscus (Option A): Involves lateral structures (lateral collateral ligament and lateral meniscus), which are not part of the unhappy triad.

Posterior cruciate ligament, medial collateral ligament, and lateral meniscus (Option C): The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) is not typically involved in this type of injury.

Medial collateral ligament, posterior cruciate ligament, and medial meniscus (Option D) The PCL is incorrectly included, as the ACL is more commonly injured in the unhappy triad.

questions.text: A patient experiences persistent shoulder pain and weakness after a fall. An MRI reveals a full-thickness rotator cuff tear. Which statement correctly describes the classification of rotator cuff tears?

choices.text: Full-thickness tears involve bursal side tear, within tendon substance
Partial-thickness tears can occur on the articular side or bursal side
Full-thickness tears are typically caused by overuse and repetitive stress
Partial-thickness tears develop gradually due to impingement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Partial-thickness tears can occur on the articular side or bursal side.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Rotator Cuff Anatomy and Tear Classification

Anatomy of the Rotator Cuff

  • Muscles Involved:
    • Supraspinatus
    • Infraspinatus
    • Teres minor
    • Subscapularis (collectively known as SITS)

Anterior view:

Posterior view:

  • Functions:
    • Stabilizes the shoulder joint
    • Assists in arm rotation and lifting
    • Controls shoulder blade movement

Role of Specific Muscles

  • Supraspinatus & Infraspinatus:
    • Keep the humeral head secure in the glenoid during arm abduction.
  • Subscapularis:
    • Stabilizes the front of the shoulder joint.
    • Prevents anterior dislocation of the humeral head.

Classification of Rotator Cuff Tears

Type

Description

Common Causes

Partial-Thickness Tears

Involve damage to some fibers of the tendon; can occur on:

Bursal side (top)

Articular side (bottom)

Within tendon substance (Option A ruled out) (Option B)

Overuse, repetitive stress (Option C ruled out)

Full-Thickness Tears

Complete rupture of the tendon; not attached to the bone

Sudden injuries (e.g., falls), gradual development due to stress or impingement (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with severe left shoulder pain, worsening over weeks, especially when raising her arm. Physical examination reveals weakness in arm abduction and tenderness along the acromion. She cannot maintain maximal external rotation during testing. Which clinical test is most likely to confirm a rotator cuff tear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lift-off test

 

Explanation:

The lift-off test assesses the strength of the subscapularis muscle. Inability to perform this test suggests a rotator cuff tear, specifically involving the subscapularis.

 

Clinical Features and Tests for Rotator Cuff Injuries

Symptoms

  • Pain: Commonly felt over the front and outer shoulder, radiating to the mid-arm. Often worsens at night; may hinder lying on the affected side.
  • Weakness: Difficulty lifting or rotating the arm.
  • Instability: Sensation of the shoulder "popping out."
  • Stiffness: Restricted arm movement.
  • Swelling: Around the shoulder joint.
  • Loss of Function: Challenges with dressing, grooming, or lifting objects.

Note: Distinguish shoulder pain from referred pain (e.g., neck or heart issues).

Signs:

Examination

Findings

Look

Scars or sinuses in skin, especially in the axilla

Shoulder asymmetry in shape and muscle bulk

Muscle wasting (deltoid, supraspinatus, infraspinatus) indicating possible nerve issues or tears

Swelling in acromioclavicular or sternoclavicular joints

Feel

Check skin temperature (inflammation typically does not affect it)

Palpate bony points (sternoclavicular joint, clavicle, acromioclavicular joint)

Locate bicipital groove

Assess tenderness along acromion (possible tendinitis or tear)

Move

Observe active movements (abduction, flexion, rotation) for symmetry and pain

Conduct passive movements while stabilizing the scapula

Assess strength of shoulder muscles (deltoid, serratus anterior, pectoralis major)

Other Systems

Examine the cervical spine for referred pain

Assess generalized joint laxity

Conduct neurological exam for nerve involvement

Special Clinical Tests

Tests for Cuff Impingement Pain

Test

Description

Painful Arc (Option B ruled out)

Pain between 60-120° active abduction, relieved by external rotation.

Neer’s Impingement Sign (Option A ruled out)

Passive flexion, abduction, and internal rotation elicit pain.

Neer’s Test for Impingement

Repeating the Neer’s sign post-anesthetic injection confirms diagnosis.

Hawkins-Kennedy Test (Option D ruled out)

Internal rotation with arm at 90° elevation causes anterolateral shoulder pain.

Tests for Isolated Weakness

Test

Description

Supraspinatus (Empty Can Test)

Weakness when resisting downward pressure on abducted arms suggests supraspinatus tear.

Infraspinatus (Resisted External Rotation)

Weakness during resisted external rotation indicates infraspinatus weakness.

Subscapularis (Belly Press Test)

Inability to press hand into abdomen indicates subscapularis weakness.

Infraspinatus and Posterior Cuff (Lag and Drop Signs)

Inability to maintain external rotation suggests tears.

Subscapularis (Lift-Off Test) (Option C)

Inability to hold their hand away from their back indicates weakness.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with shoulder pain and limited range of motion after a fall. An X-ray is performed to evaluate for rotator cuff injuries. Which of the following findings would not typically be associated with rotator cuff injuries?

choices.text: Erosion and sclerosis at the greater tuberosity
Upward displacement of the humeral head
Joint space narrowing of the acromioclavicular joint
Presence of a well-defined calcific deposit within the deltoid muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Presence of a well-defined calcific deposit within the deltoid muscle

 

Explanation:

Presence of a well-defined calcific deposit within the deltoid muscle: This finding is not associated with rotator cuff injuries; calcifications are usually located in the supraspinatus tendon rather than the deltoid muscle.

X-ray Findings in Rotator Cuff Injuries

  • Role of X-rays:
    • Not the primary method for diagnosing rotator cuff tears.
    • Useful for identifying bony abnormalities and related pathologies.

Findings Based on Condition

Condition

X-ray Findings

Early Cuff Dysfunction
  • Typically normal X-rays in initial rotator cuff impingement or tendinitis stages.

Chronic Tendinitis
  • Erosion, sclerosis, or cysts at tendon insertion on greater tuberosity (thin sclerosis band).(Option A ruled out)
  • Acromion Changes: Roughening/overgrowth at anterior edge, thinning of the acromion, upward humeral head displacement on caudal tilt view.
  • Acromioclavicular Osteoarthritis: Joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis, especially in older patients. (Option C ruled out)

Cuff Disruption
  • Upward Humeral Head Displacement: Decreased subacromial space due to ineffective stabilization from torn rotator cuff. (Option B ruled out)
  • Glenohumeral Osteoarthritis: Develops from altered mechanics and instability over time.

Acute Calcific Tendinitis
  • Calcification above greater tuberosity in supraspinatus tendon, changing from well-defined to “woolly” during resorption, and may eventually resolve. (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with shoulder pain and weakness after a fall. Imaging reveals a rotator cuff tear. Which of the following imaging modalities is considered the gold standard for diagnosing intra-articular shoulder pathologies, including rotator cuff tears?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MR Arthroscopy (MRA)

 

Explanation:

MR Arthroscopy (MRA) is the gold standard for detecting intra-articular shoulder pathologies. It provides superior visualization of subtle rotator cuff injuries, labral tears, and other soft tissue structures compared to standard MRI, especially in younger or active individuals

Investigations for Rotator Cuff Injuries

Investigation Method

Description

X-rays (Option B ruled out)

Useful for identifying bony abnormalities and calcifications.

Arthrography

Injects contrast into the shoulder joint to visualize the rotator cuff and glenoid labrum; often combined with CT or MRI.

Computed Tomography (CT) (Option D ruled out)

Aids in surgical planning for procedures like shoulder replacement; CT arthrography identifies tears but is largely replaced by MRA.

Ultrasound (Option A ruled out)

Real-time imaging for detecting rotator cuff tears and biceps tendon issues; operator-dependent for interpretation.

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Excellent for visualizing soft tissue structures, assessing tear size, fatty infiltration, and joint evaluation.

Magnetic Resonance Arthrography (MRA) (Option C)

Highly sensitive for detecting labral tears and partial rotator cuff tears using contrast.

Arthroscopy

Minimally invasive procedure for diagnosing and treating intra-articular shoulder pathologies, considered the gold standard.

Conditions Diagnosed via Arthroscopy

Condition

Description

Rotator cuff tears

Includes partial or full-thickness tears.

Labral detachments

Includes SLAP lesions.

Impingement syndrome

Affects shoulder movement and pain.

Frozen shoulder (adhesive capsulitis)

Restricted shoulder mobility.

Treatment of Rotator Cuff Injuries

Conservative Treatment Options

Treatment Option

Description

Activity Modification

Avoid activities that worsen pain, particularly those in the "impingement position."

Physiotherapy

Focus on strengthening rotator cuff muscles, scapular stability, and shoulder range of motion.

Medications

NSAIDs reduce pain/inflammation; corticosteroid injections provide temporary relief.

Extracorporeal Shockwave Therapy

Treats calcific tendinitis; less effective than needle aspiration or surgery.

Needle Aspiration and Irrigation (Barbotage)

Ultrasound-guided procedure to remove calcific deposits; effective in acute cases.

Surgical Treatment Options

Surgical Procedure

Description

Open Acromioplasty

Involves removing part of the acromion to reduce impingement; largely replaced by arthroscopic methods.

Arthroscopic Acromioplasty

Minimally invasive procedure with smaller incisions, less tissue disruption, and faster recovery.

Open Rotator Cuff Repair

Reattaches torn tendon to humerus; requires longer recovery.

Arthroscopic Rotator Cuff Repair

Minimally invasive; faster rehabilitation and less postoperative pain.

Biceps Tenodesis

Reattaches the long head of the biceps tendon for stability.

SLAP Lesion Repair

Arthroscopic procedure to repair superior labrum tears; may involve biceps tenodesis.

Capsular Release (for Frozen Shoulder)

Releases contracted capsular tissue to improve range of motion.
